maml:description.maml:para: Close a SQLite database file.

If you are creating your own solutions using the MySQLite module, you might need to open and close the database file. If you use Invoke-MySQLite to insert or update data, that command will handle opening and closing the file.
Enter a connection object.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter a connection object.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $connection = Open-MySQLiteDB -Path C:\work\test2.db PS C:\> Close-mySQLiteDB $connection

dev:remarks.maml:para: After opening the connection and making any changes, you should close the connection.

maml:description.maml:para: Convert a MySQLite property blob

Nested object properites are stored as blobs. When you specify such a property using ConvertTo-MySQLiteDB, it is exported using Export-Clixml. The content of the resulting text file is converted to a byte array which is stored in the database table. ConvertFrom-MySQLiteDB should automatically convert it back to a deserialized version of the original object. You can use this stand-alone function to handle the conversion yourself.
Specify the byte array from the blob property.
Specify the byte array from the blob property.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Invoke-MySQLiteQuery -path D:\temp\myproc.db -Query "Select name,id,ws,totalprocessortime from process where id=6624" | Select-Object name,id,ws,@{Name="TotalCPU";Expression = {Convert-MySQLiteByteArray $_.totalprocessortime}}
Name ID WS TotalCPU ---- -- -- -------- sqlservr 6624 778153984 00:00:58.0468750

dev:remarks.maml:para: The TotalProcessTime property will be returned as a byte array. Convert-MySQLiteByteArray restores it to its original form.

maml:description.maml:para: Convert a table from a SQLite database.

This command is intended primarily to dump or convert a table from a SQLite database file into PowerShell. It is assumed you create the table using ConvertTo-MySQLiteDB but this should work for most tables. To get the best results you will want to specify a mapping table of keys and datatypes. If you used ConvertTo-MySQLiteDB, it will create a corresponding property map table that you can use. Otherwise, you can use a hashtable. If you want to let SQLite do its best, you can use the -RawObject parameter.

NOTE: Storing objects in a database requires serializing nested objects. This is accomplished by converting objects to cliXML and storing that information as an array of bytes in the database. To convert back, the data must be converted to the original clixml string, saved to a temporary file, and then re-imported with `Import-Clixml`. This process is not guaranteed to be 100% error free. The converted object property should be the deserialized version of the original property.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file.
Enter an optional hashtable of property names and types.
Enter the name of the table with data to import.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file.
Enter the name of the property map table that is part of the database.
Enter the name of the table with data to import.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file.
Write raw objects to the pipeline. PowerShell will make its best guess as an appropriate datatype.
Enter the name of the table with data to import.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file.
Enter an optional hashtable of property names and types.
Enter the name of the property map table that is part of the database.
Write raw objects to the pipeline. PowerShell will make its best guess as an appropriate datatype.
Enter the name of the table with data to import.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> ConvertFrom-MySQLiteDB -Path C:\work\Inventory.db -TableName OS -PropertyTable propertymap_myos
Computername : SRV2 OS : Microsoft Windows Server 2016 Standard Evaluation InstallDate : 10/26/2020 6:56:32 PM Version : 10.0.14393 IsServer : True
Computername : SRV1 OS : Microsoft Windows Server 2016 Standard Evaluation InstallDate : 10/26/2020 6:56:33 PM Version : 10.0.14393 IsServer : True ...

dev:remarks.maml:para: Dump a table created using ConvertTo-MySQLiteDB. The resulting objects will have a type name of myOS which is derived from the property map table name which was also created by ConvertTo-MySQLiteDB. As an alternative, you can specify a different type name.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> ConvertFrom-MySQLiteDB -Path C:\work\test.db -TableName proc -PropertyMap @{Name="string";Date="datetime";id="int";virtualmemorysize = "int";workingset="int"} | Get-Member
TypeName: System.Management.Automation.PSCustomObject
Name MemberType Definition ---- ---------- ---------- Equals Method bool Equals(System.Object obj) GetHashCode Method int GetHashCode() GetType Method type GetType() ToString Method string ToString() Date NoteProperty datetime Date=3/13/2020 2:52:14 PM id NoteProperty int id=17276 Name NoteProperty string Name=ApplicationFrameHost virtualmemorysize NoteProperty int virtualmemorysize=295845888 workingset NoteProperty int workingset=11640832

dev:remarks.maml:para: Convert a table using a hashtable of property assignments.

maml:description.maml:para: Convert or dump PowerShell objects into a SQLite database.

This command is designed to make it easy to take the results of a PowerShell expression, or a collection of objects, and dump them into a SQLite database file. You will need to specify a table name for the data. By default, the command will create a corresponding property map table so that it will be easier to get the data back out with ConvertFrom-MySQLiteDB. This command will use the detected typename or you can specify a typename.

This command was designed with the assumption that you would create a single database and table per command. The Append parameter allows you to include additional tables in the same database file. It does NOT append data to an existing table. If you need to do that, create an Insert query with Invoke-MySQLiteQuery.
Nested objects or more complex properties will be converted to cliXML and stored in the database as byte array or blob.
This command will not overwrite an existing file unless you use -Force.
For best results, you should select only the properties you need as some properties may not serialize very well.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file.
Append a new table to an existing SQLite database file. This does NOT append data to an existing table.
Overwrite the existing file.
Enter the name of the new table. Table names are technically case-sensitive.
Enter a typename for your converted objects. If you don't specify one, it will be auto-detected. This name will also be used to construct the property map table.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
What object do you want to create? Typically this will be the result of a PowerShell expression or command. It is recommended that you be selective.
Specify the column name to use as the primary key or index. Otherwise, the first detected property will be used.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file.
Append a new table to an existing SQLite database file. This does NOT append data to an existing table.
Overwrite the existing file.
Enter the name of the new table. Table names are technically case-sensitive.
Enter a typename for your converted objects. If you don't specify one, it will be auto-detected. This name will also be used to construct the property map table.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
What object do you want to create? Typically this will be the result of a PowerShell expression or command. It is recommended that you be selective.
Specify the column name to use as the primary key or index. Otherwise, the first detected property will be used.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $data = Get-CimInstance win32_operatingsystem -ComputerName $computers | Select-Object @{Name="Computername";Expression={$_.CSName}},@{Name="OS";Expression = {$_.caption}},InstallDate,Version,@{Name="IsServer";Expression={ If ($_.caption -match "server") {$True} else {$False}}} PS C:\> $data | ConvertTo-MySQLiteDB -Path c:\work\Inventory.db -TableName OS -TypeName myOS -force

dev:remarks.maml:para: Convert the results of a PowerShell expression into a SQLite database file using a table called OS and a custom type name of myOS. This process will also create a table called propertymap_myOS with mappings for property names and the original type.
The first property name will be used as the first table column and the primary index so the values from your command need to be unique.
The database can be queried using Invoke-MYSQLiteQuery or dumped out using ConvertFrom-MySQLiteDB.

NOTE: Storing objects in a database requires serializing nested objects. This is accomplished by converting objects to cliXML and storing that information as an array of bytes in the database. To convert back, the data must be converted to the original clixml string, saved to a temporary file, and then re-imported with `Import-Clixml`. This process is not guaranteed to be 100% error free. The converted object property should be the deserialized version of the original property.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-Process | Where-Object {$_.name -notmatch "^(system|idle)$"} | Select * | ConvertTo-MySQLiteDB -Path d:\temp\allproc.db -TableName Process -TypeName myProcess -Primary ID

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a database from local process information. This example is specifying the primary key. You need to have one unique property to use as the primary key for the database. If you see a constraint error, you most likely need to set a primary key.

maml:description.maml:para: Export a SQLite database file

This command is provided as backup mechanism for a SQLite database file. The function will export all tables and data to a JSON file. Use Import-MySQLiteDB to restore the database using the JSON file.
The path to the SQLite database file. It must have a .db extension.
The destination path for the exported JSON file.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The destination path for the exported JSON file.
The path to the SQLite database file. It must have a .db extension.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Export-MySQLiteDB -path c:\work\inventory.db -destination d:\inventory.json

maml:description.maml:para: Get information about a SQLite database
Use this command to retrieve information about a SQLite database file.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-MySQLiteDB -Path C:\work\test.db
Path FileName Size Modified Tables ---- -------- ---- -------- ------ C:\work\test.db test.db 33792 3/13/2020 3:22:00 PM {Metadata, PropertyMap, Domain, Data...}

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get information for a single database.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get information for multiple database files sorted by size.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-MySQLiteDB c:\work\vm2.db | Select-object -Property *
DatabaseName : main Tables : {Metadata, PropertyMap, virtualmachines, Switches} PageSize : 1024 PageCount : 14 Encoding : UTF-8 FileName : vm2.db Path : C:\work\vm2.db Size : 14336 Created : 3/8/2019 2:49:43 PM Modified : 3/13/2019 3:57:23 PM Age : 00:12:53.1287578 SQLiteVersion : 3.8.8.3

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get all properties of a SQLite database file.

maml:description.maml:para: Get information about tables in a SQLite database.
Use this command to discover table names and layout in a SQLite database file.
Specify an existing open database connection.
Display formatted detail results.
Do not close the database connection.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file.
Display formatted detail results.
Specify an existing open database connection.
Display formatted detail results.
Do not close the database connection.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-MySQLiteTable -Path c:\work\vm2.db
Source Name ------ ---- C:\work\vm2.db {Metadata, PropertyMap, virtualmachines, Switches}

dev:remarks.maml:para: Basic information about available tables.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-MySQLiteTable -Path c:\work\vm2.db -Detail
Database C:\work\vm2.db Table:Metadata
ColumnIndex ColumnName ColumnType ----------- ---------- ---------- 0 Author TEXT 1 Created TEXT 2 Computername TEXT 3 Comment TEXT
Database C:\work\vm2.db Table:PropertyMap
ColumnIndex ColumnName ColumnType ----------- ---------- ---------- 0 Name 1 State 2 Runtime 3 SizeGB 4 VMSwitch 5 MemoryMB 6 MemoryDemandMB 7 IPAddress 8 Date 9 ComputerName
Database C:\work\vm2.db Table:virtualmachines
ColumnIndex ColumnName ColumnType ----------- ---------- ---------- 0 Name Text 1 State Blob 2 Runtime Blob 3 SizeGB Real 4 VMSwitch Text 5 MemoryMB Real 6 MemoryDemandMB Real 7 IPAddress Text 8 Date Text 9 ComputerName Text
Database C:\work\vm2.db Table:Switches
ColumnIndex ColumnName ColumnType ----------- ---------- ---------- 0 Name

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get a detailed report on tables in the specified file.

maml:description.maml:para: Import a SQLite database backup

If you exported a SQLite database to a JSON file using Export-MySQLiteDB, you can use this file import the data and recreate the file. If you want to restore an existing file, it is recommended restore to a different location, verify the new database, and then copy over the existing file.
The path to the exported JSON file.
The destination path for the imported database file. It must have a .db file extension.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Overwrite the destination database file if it exists.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The destination path for the imported database file. It must have a .db file extension.
Overwrite the destination database file if it exists.
The path to the exported JSON file.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Import-MySQLiteDB -path c:\work\inventory.json-destination d:\temp\inventory.db.

maml:description.maml:para: Invoke a query on a SQLite database

Use this command to run a SQL query against a SQLite database. You can use this command to get data from a table,insert data into a table or modify data. If you are running a SELECT query, which normally returns something, you have an option as to how you would like the results to be formatted.
You will normally use the Path parameter. In scripts, you are more likely to use an existing connection.
See https://sqlite.org/lang.html and http://www.sqlitetutorial.net/ for additional help.
Specify an existing open database connection.
Enter a SQL query string. See http://www.sqlitetutorial.net/ for some guidance.
Write the results of a Select query in the specified format. The default is as an object, but you can get the results as a DataTable or HashTable.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Keep the connection alive.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file.
Enter a SQL query string. See http://www.sqlitetutorial.net/ for some guidance.
Write the results of a Select query in the specified format. The default is as an object, but you can get the results as a DataTable or HashTable.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Write the results of a Select query in the specified format. The default is as an object, but you can get the results as a DataTable or HashTable.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specify an existing open database connection.
Keep the connection alive.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file.
Enter a SQL query string. See http://www.sqlitetutorial.net/ for some guidance.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $data = Get-Process | Select-object ID,Name,Workingset,VirtualMemorySize,@{Name="Date";Expression={Get-Date}} PS C:\> $data | foreach-object -begin { $cx = Open-MySQLiteDB c:\work\test.db} -process { Invoke-MySQLiteQuery -connection $cx -keepalive -query "Insert into proc Values ('$($_.ID)','$($_.Name)','$($_.Workingset)','$($_.VirtualMemorySize)','$($_.Date)') "} -end { Close-MySQLiteDB $cx} PS C:\> Invoke-MySQLiteQuery -Path c:\work\test.db -Query "Select * from proc Order by Workingset Desc Limit 5" | format-table
ID Name Workingset VirtualMemorySize Date -- ---- ---------- ----------------- ---- 3112 Memory Compression 1340776448 1484521472 03/13/2022 14:52:14 5684 powershell 1198268416 -2013696000 03/13/2022 14:52:14 12232 firefox 370966528 -1868365824 03/13/2022 14:52:14 15536 thunderbird 347189248 1131708416 03/13/2022 14:52:14 15788 Code 323653632 1997750272 03/13/2022 14:52:14

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command creates a data set. The second command inserts into a table in the SQLite database file. The last command queries for data in the proc table sorting on the WorkingSet property in descending order. Note that you could have retrieved all data from the table and piped to Where-Object to perform the filtering, but that would not be as efficient.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Invoke-MySQLiteQuery c:\work\vm2.db -Query "update metadata set Comment = 'for Hyper-V monitoring'" PS C:\> Invoke-MySQLiteQuery c:\work\vm2.db -Query "select * from Metadata"
Author Created Computername Comment ------ ------- ------------ ------- BOVINE320\Jeff 3/8/2022 2:59:05 PM BOVINE320 for Hyper-V monitoring

dev:remarks.maml:para: Update a table column and then query the results

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new SQLite database file

This command will create a new SQLite database file. It won't create any tables other than a Metadata table with information about who created the database and when. You can use the -Comment parameter to include a description or additional information into the Metadata table.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file you want to create.
Enter a comment to be inserted into the database's metadata table.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Enter a comment to be inserted into the database's metadata table.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file you want to create.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-MySQLiteDB c:\work\test.db

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a new database file in C:\Work.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> New-MySQLiteDB c:\work\test2.db -Comment "This is for scripting stuff" -passthru -force | Invoke-MySQLiteQuery -query "Select * from metadata"
Author Created Computername Comment ------ ------- ------------ ------- THINKX1-JH\Jeff 7/20/2022 12:34:39 PM THINKX1-JH This is for scripting stuff

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a new database file in C:\Work and add a comment. Overwrite the file if it already exists and send the result to Invoke-MySQLiteQuery to display metadata information.

maml:description.maml:para: This command will create a new table in a SQLite database file. You need to specify a table name. When you define the table you also need to specify the column names. You can do this with an array of names, in which case the column values will not be treated as any particular type. When you insert data into the table SQLite will automatically determine a type.
Or you can use an ordered hashtable of column names and types. The first key will be set as the Primary key unless you specify one.

Normally you will specify a path but in scripted projects, you may have an existing connection and wish to re-use it to avoid file I/O overhead. In any event, the database must already have been created.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Overwrite an existing table. This could result in data loss.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file.
Enter the name of the new table. Table names are technically case-sensitive.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specify the column name to use as the primary key or index. Otherwise, the first detected property will be used.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Overwrite an existing table. This could result in data loss.
If using a connection, keep the connection open and alive when the command finishes.
Enter the name of the new table. Table names are technically case-sensitive.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specify the column name to use as the primary key or index. Otherwise, the first detected property will be used.
Enter an ordered hashtable of column definitions. See https://www.sqlite.org/datatype3.html for more information about supported types.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Overwrite an existing table. This could result in data loss.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file.
Enter the name of the new table. Table names are technically case-sensitive.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specify the column name to use as the primary key or index. Otherwise, the first detected property will be used.
Enter an ordered hashtable of column definitions. See https://www.sqlite.org/datatype3.html for more information about supported types.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Overwrite an existing table. This could result in data loss.
If using a connection, keep the connection open and alive when the command finishes.
Enter the name of the new table. Table names are technically case-sensitive.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specify the column name to use as the primary key or index. Otherwise, the first detected property will be used.
Enter an ordered hashtable of column definitions. See https://www.sqlite.org/datatype3.html for more information about supported types.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Overwrite an existing table. This could result in data loss.
If using a connection, keep the connection open and alive when the command finishes.
Enter the path to the SQLite database file.
Enter the name of the new table. Table names are technically case-sensitive.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specify the column name to use as the primary key or index. Otherwise, the first detected property will be used.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-MySQLiteDBTable -Path c:\work\test.db -TableName Data -ColumnNames "Name","Date","Size"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This adds a new table to the database file c:\work\test.db called Data. The table will have 3 columns and any data inserted into it will be automatically typed.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $h = [ordered]@{ID="Int";Name="Text";Workingset="Int";VirtualMemorySize="Int";Date="text"} PS C:\> New-MySQLiteDBTable -Path c:\work\test.db -TableName Proc -ColumnProperties $h PS C:\> Invoke-MySQLiteQuery c:\work\test.db -query "Pragma table_info(proc)" | Select-Object Cid,Name,Type
cid name type --- ---- ---- 0 ID Int 1 Name Text 2 Workingset Int 3 VirtualMemorySize Int 4 Date text

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command creates an ordered hashtable of column names and types. The second command creates a new table called Proc and the last command validates the new table. The cid property is the column index number.
Note that SQLite has a limited number of supported types. See https://www.sqlite.org/datatype3.html for more information.

maml:description.maml:para: Open a SQLite database file.

If you are creating your own solutions using the MySQLite module, you might need to open and close the database file. If you use Invoke-MySQLite to insert or update data, that command will handle opening and closing the file.
The path to the SQLite database file.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The path to the SQLite database file.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $connection = Open-MySQLiteDB -Path C:\work\test2.db PS C:\> $connection
PoolCount : 0 ConnectionString : Data Source=C:\work\test2.db;Version=3 DataSource : test2 FileName : C:\work\test2.db Database : main DefaultTimeout : 30 BusyTimeout : 0 WaitTimeout : 30000 PrepareRetries : 3 ProgressOps : 0 ParseViaFramework : False Flags : Default DefaultDbType : DefaultTypeName : VfsName : OwnHandle : True ServerVersion : 3.28.0 LastInsertRowId : 0 Changes : 0 AutoCommit : True MemoryUsed : 133912 MemoryHighwater : 312684 State : Open ConnectionTimeout : 15 CanCreateBatch : False Site : Container :

dev:remarks.maml:para: You can use the open connection object with commands in the mySQLite module that have a connection parameter.
